Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Networking Infrastructure: Capacity and Capability Network Enhancements to Support Data-Driven Research at the University of Arkansas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project upgrades University of Arkansas (UA) campus and shared network infrastructure provided by the Arkansas Research and Education Optical Network (ARE ON), which connects institutions of higher education in Arkansas. These upgrades increase ARE-ON's backbone bandwidth to 100 Gbps between the UA and the Internet2 point-of-presence (PoP) in Tulsa, OK, provide scalable bandwidth greater than 10 Gbps to an existing science DMZ at the UA, and create a 10 Gbps science DMZ at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock (UALR). The result is a faster, more reliable network connection for the UA and for 35 other ARE-ON universities, colleges, two-year institutions, and educational affiliates. The project also provides connectivity to the Internet2 Advanced Layer 2 Service with support for OpenFlow traffic between ARE-ON members and other Internet2 member institutions, and OpenFlow tagging and traffic management on the UA and UALR campuses. These upgrades provide needed capacity to meet research needs and will enable new network services such as dynamically provisioned layer 2 circuits in support of specific data intensive and instrument-related research collaborations and training programs that will have state, national and international scope.

The new network capabilities will enable research in human and agricultural genetics powered by XSEDE computing resources, the development and characterization of novel materials at the Institute for Nanoscience and Engineering, and will provide a technical framework for research, education and training in software defined networking for the UA and other institutions in the state.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project signifficantly upgraded the University of Arkansas (UA) campus and shared network infrastructure provided by the Arkansas Research and Education Optical Network (ARE-ON), which connects institutions of higher education in Arkansas. The upgrades increased AREON’s backbone bandwidth to 100 Gbps between the UA and the Internet2 PoP in Tulsa, OK, and now provides scalable bandwidth greater than 10 Gbps to an existing science DMZ at the UA. In addition to bandwidth upgrades the network enhancements provide greater reliability and redundancy directly affecting 35 AREON universities, colleges, two-year institutions, and educational affiliates. The project also provided connectivity to the Internet2 Advanced Layer 2 Service, support for OpenFlow traffic between AREON members and other Internet2 member institutions, and OpenFlow tagging and traffic management on two University of Arkansas System campuses. These upgrades provide needed capacity to meet research needs and enable new network services including dynamically provisioned layer 2 circuits in support of specific data intensive and instrument-related research collaborations and training programs that will have state, national and international scope.

Intellectual Merit – The University of Arkansas is collaborating with AREON to build research leadership capacity for the state and the region in life sciences (particularly agricultural –omics), geosciences and nanomaterials. Because of the state’s unique position bridging the Mississippi Delta and the plains of Oklahoma, a number of other research areas have become important that are heavily influenced by global climate change and national economic shifts: energy exploration and extraction, alternative biofuels production, animal and plant food production and safety, agile advanced manufacturing and logistics. This diverse research portfolio is heavily dependent on collaboration at all scales and by data-intensive computing and analytics. To meet the growing demands of these data-intensive research programs for moving very large data sets between instruments, storage and computing facilities, this project provided regional 100 Gbps layer 2 and layer 3 connectivity, initially between the UA, AREON, and Internet2. This connectivity will also build capacity and research capability between (four) regional optical networks: AREON, OneNet, Oklahoma’s research and education network; the Great Plains Network (GPN); and MORENet, Missouri’s R&E network. GPN is also a regional hub for Internet2, and connecting state networks in Kansas, Nebraska, South Dakota, Wisconsin, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Missouri.

Within the State of Arkansas the upgrades directly support research, research training and education at the UA and a broad range of other educational institutions in Arkansas. Leading research projects to supported include 1) EPSCoR-supported research centers including the Arkansas Plant-Powered Production Center, Arkansas GREEN Solar Cells Research Center, Vertically-Integrated Center for Transformative Energy Research; 2) development of educational programs in computational science, bioinformatics, nanotechnology, and computer science; 3) fundamental network research in network security. Education programs we expect to support and further enable include life sciences education programs aimed at establishing STEM pipelines for students from underrepresented groups bridging two and four year higher education institutions with research intensive universities.

Broader Impact – Because of the ubiquity and necessity of network connectivity in the life of higher education institutions the enhancements to cyberconnectivity are having and will continue to have a profound and direct affect on all research, education and training efforts conducted at the University of Arkansas and other AREON member institutions, as well as benefits to interactions between the research intensive institutions of higher education and four year and two year institutions and for public science outreach efforts. The project will also explore and develop models of how these services can be used to build new collaborative research, learning and knowledge sharing communities that include experts and learners at many organizations across the state and region through specific projects spanning two-year colleges to research institutions that leverage advanced network services, and through workshops.
